issue.title: Similar to opt-out on annotated element via ignoreAnnotated, could we have an opt-in mechanise
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior
n-a

## Current Behavior
n-a

## Context
I want to enable an existing rule but only for Jetpack Compose (via `detekt.yml`). 

The rule should apply to all public functions annotated with `@Composable`. 

Currently I can only do the inverse with `ignoreAnnotated`. 

And it seems the only way to do it now is by writing a custom rule which seems a litter overkill for what I want to do. 

For context, the rule I want to activate is `UndocumentedPublicFunction`.

Using `detekt = "1.23.1"`

issue.title: Fix by adding last method call to the set

pull_request.title: Remove `Debt`
pull_request.body:
Right now the concept of `Debt` is only used to show it on the docuentation (second commit) and to show it in two different console reports (third commit). We don't even show `Debt` values in the html report. For that reason I think that we should remove it.

If we don't want to remove it I think that we should give it a bit of love:
- #4359 
- Show it on html report (at least)
- Review if the debt values have sense for each rule

And I don't see us doing that. For that reason I vote to remove it. Also, if someone wants to keep this functinality (or even improve it) that's doable with our extension points, so any third party could implement it if they see value on that.

I recommend to review this PR by commits so you can see exactly what "features" I'm removing.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,34 +2,79 @@ package io.gitlab.arturbosch.detekt.core.suppressors
 
 import io.gitlab.arturbosch.detekt.api.AnnotationExcluder
 import io.gitlab.arturbosch.detekt.api.ConfigAware
+import io.gitlab.arturbosch.detekt.api.Finding
 import org.jetbrains.kotlin.psi.KtAnnotated
 import org.jetbrains.kotlin.psi.KtElement
 import org.jetbrains.kotlin.psi.psiUtil.getStrictParentOfType
 import org.jetbrains.kotlin.resolve.BindingContext
 
+private class IgnoreAnnotationSuppressor(
+    private val ignoreAnnotations: List<Regex>,
+    private val bindingContext: BindingContext,
+    private val shouldContainAnnotation: Boolean
+) : Suppressor {
+
+    override fun shouldSuppress(finding: Finding): Boolean {
+        val element = finding.entity.ktElement
+        return element != null && !shouldContainAnnotation == element.isAnnotatedWith(
+            AnnotationExcluder(element.containingKtFile, ignoreAnnotations, bindingContext),
+        )
+    }
+}
+
 /**
  * Suppress all the issues that are raised under a code that is annotated with the annotations defined at
  * `ignoreAnnotated`.
  *
  * @config ignoreAnnotated: List<String> The annotations can be defined just by its name or with its fully qualified
  * name. If you don't run detekt with type solving the fully qualified name does not work.
  */
-internal fun annotationSuppressorFactory(rule: ConfigAware, bindingContext: BindingContext): Suppressor? {
-    val annotations = rule.valueOrDefault("ignoreAnnotated", emptyList<String>()).map {
-        it.qualifiedNameGlobToRegex()
-    }
+internal fun ignoreAnnotationSuppressorFactory(rule: ConfigAware, bindingContext: BindingContext): Suppressor? {
+    return annotationSuppressorFactory(rule, bindingContext, "ignoreAnnotated", false)
+}
+
+/**
+ * Suppress all the issues that are raised under a code that is not annotated with the annotations defined at
+ * `ignoreAnnotated`.
+ *
+ * @config ignoreAnnotated: List<String> The annotations can be defined just by its name or with its fully qualified
+ * name. If you don't run detekt with type solving the fully qualified name does not work.
+ */
+internal fun onlyAnnotationSuppressorFactory(rule: ConfigAware, bindingContext: BindingContext): Suppressor? {
+    return annotationSuppressorFactory(rule, bindingContext, "onlyAnnotated", true)
comment.body: Nope docs update goes in the same PR when a new config is added

pull_request.title: Implement rules suggesting to convert statements to expressions
pull_request.body:
The rules detect `if` and `when` statements that can be converted to expressions. They check if the statements are exhaustive and if the last statements of each branch allow a conversion.

The change fixes #6233.

issue.title: Always use Named Arguments with booleans
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior of the rule

Noncompliant
```kotlin
User("Brais", false)

getUser(id, true)
```

Compliant
```kotlin
User("Brais", isActive = false)

getUser(id, forceRefresh = true)

getUser(id, refresh)
```

## Context
A boolean as a parameter creates difficult code to review:

For example if you have this `data class`:
```kotlin
User(
  val name: String,
  val isActive: Boolean,
  val isPro: Boolean,
)
```

This code is really dificult to understand: `User("Brais", false, true)`. It's kind of easy to understand that `"Brais"` is the name of the user. But it's impossible to know if this user `isActive` or if it `isPro`. If you want to know it you need check the User definition.

With only one parameter the code is a bit better but the problem is still there.

I know that this is a bit subjective and there are other good cases to use argument parameters not adressed here. But I think that the boolean is a real common case that a lot of detekt users can use.

commits.message:
Add UnnamedParameterUse rule (#6055)

Co-authored-by: Brais Gabín <braisgabin@gmail.com>
